div.l: And greten hym and toke his horse Anone
And eke her Mele ⁊and on the waye þey gone
And atte Mylle yette they toke þe Caake
Of halfe A busschelle Flowre Fulle well ybake
Thus is the proude Myller well ybete
And haþe yloste the gryndenge of the whete
And payede For the Souper eueridele
Of Aleyn ⁊and of Iohn þat bete hym wele
His wyfe is swyuede And his doughter als
Loo sucche itt is A Myller to be False
And þ̉erfore this prouerbe is sayde Fulle Soþe
He þare notte weene wele þat euylle doþe
A gyler schall hym Selfe bigylede be
And god þat Syttethe hyghe in Mageste
Saue all þis Companye grete ⁊and Smale
Thus haue I qwytte the Myller in my tale
Here endith the take of the reve and
Begynnyth the prolog of the Cooke
The Cooke of london whyle the Reue spake
Foe ioye hym þoughte he clawede hym on his backe
Ha · ha · qduod he For Cristes passioun
This Myller haþe A scharpe conclucioun
Vppon his Argumente of herborage
Well sayde Sallamon in his language
Ne brynge notte euery Man into þyne house
For harborenge by nyghte is ꝑperylouse
Well aughte A Man Auysede For to be
Whome he broughte into his preuyte
I praye to god So yeue me sorrowe ⁊and care
Yefe eủer I sythen hyghte hogge of ware
Harde A Myller better sette Awerke
He hadde A Iape of Malyce in the derke
